episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a range of quirky historical and scientific facts, including the peculiar regulations around alcohol service on flights in 1950s America, the use of old tins of fish to study ocean health, a German writer's unusual method of treating ghostly visions, and the criminalization of pager ownership among youths in the 1980s.

facts.fact: In 1950s America, flight attendants consulted an alcohol chart of the sky so they knew when they were allowed to serve booze.
A team of ecologists have been studying the health of the oceans by dissecting leftover tins of fish from the 1980s.
German writer Christoph Friedrich Nicolai treated his visions of ghosts by applying leeches to his anus.
In some American states and cities in the late 80s, children could be sent to prison for six months for the crime of owning a pager.
